questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain and dysuria. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections that have resolved with antibiotic treatment. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they do not use condoms. She had mild pain during her last sexual intercourse 1 week ago. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows lower abdominal tenderness and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a small amount of purulent vaginal discharge. Bimanual examination shows uterine and cervical motion tenderness. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
12 g/dL


Leukocyte count
13,500/mm3



 Segmented neutrophils
75%


 Eosinophils
1%


 Lymphocytes
22%


 Monocytes
2%


Platelet count
328,000/mm3



Erythrocyte sedimentation rate
82 mm/h


Urine



 RBC
1–2/hpf


 WBC
0–1/hpf


 Nitrite
negative


 Bacteria
occasional


Urine pregnancy test
negative


Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: Intramuscular ceftriaxone, oral doxycycline, and oral metronidazole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is effective against infection with anaerobic protozoa and should be part of the empiric antibiotic regimen for PID. Metronidazole alone, however, does not cover the most typical causative pathogens of PID, i.e., N. gonorrhea and C. trachomatis.

B) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of PID. Oral azithromycin can be used to treat infection with Chlamydia trachomatis, which is one of the most common causative organisms of PID, but another regimen is preferred. Furthermore, PID should also be treated with antibiotics that provide anaerobic coverage.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral administration of levofloxacin and metronidazole is suitable for treating PID in patients with cephalosporin allergies. This patient has no history of allergy; a different regimen is preferred.

D) CORRECT:

PID is a clinical diagnosis that is made in sexually active individuals with abdominal and/or pelvic pain if there is no other suspected cause and pelvic examination shows adnexal, uterine, and/or cervical motion tenderness. Patients with PID should be treated with empiric antibiotic therapy that targets the most common causative pathogens, i.e., Neisseria gonorrhoeae (ceftriaxone) and Chlamydia trachomatis (doxycycline), and also covers anaerobes (metronidazole). Outpatient care is preferred for uncomplicated PID. Patients with complicating factors (e.g., pregnancy, suspected tuboovarian abscess, high fever) should be hospitalized and treated with intravenous antibiotics.

Patients with PID should be advised to abstain from sexual activity until antibiotic therapy has been completed, symptoms have resolved, and sexual partners have been treated. All patients diagnosed with PID should also undergo testing for other sexually transmitted infections, including HIV and syphilis.

E) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is typically recommended for the treatment of PID because it covers N. gonorrhoeae, one of the most common causative pathogens. However, empiric antibiotic treatment for PID should also provide coverage for Chlamydia trachomatis, another common causative pathogen, and anaerobes. Ceftriaxone therapy alone is inappropriate.
questions.hint: The onset of lower abdominal pain, dysuria, dyspareunia, and purulent vaginal discharge, in conjunction with uterine and cervical motion tenderness in a sexually active woman, is highly suggestive of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

questions.text: A previously healthy 28-year-old woman comes to the physician because of lower abdominal pain and purulent vaginal discharge for the past 5 days. Menses occur at irregular 20- and 40-day intervals and last 4 to 8 days. She is sexually active with a new partner whom she met 3 months ago, and they use condoms inconsistently. She had a normal Pap smear 5 months ago. She drinks 2 beers every other day. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F), pulse is 85/min, and blood pressure is 108/75 mm Hg. Examination shows lower abdominal tenderness and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. Pelvic examination is notable for uterine and adnexal tenderness and small amounts of bloody cervical discharge. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 14,500/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 90 mm/h. A spot urine pregnancy test is negative. An endocervical swab is obtained for nucleic acid amplification testing. The patient is started on ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Typical imaging findings of PID (e.g., edematous, fluid-filled ovarian tubes, free pelvic fluid, and tuboovarian abscesses) can support the diagnosis, and imaging might be warranted if the diagnosis remains unclear or if symptoms persist after empiric treatment. However, when imaging is indicated, either transvaginal ultrasound (US) or MRI is preferred because CT scan involves exposure to radiation and does not provide more diagnostic information than these modalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Tzanck smear is used to detect herpes simplex virus (HSV) 1 and 2 infections. Although this patient is at risk for developing genital herpes, which may cause vaginal discharge, she does not have characteristic genital vesicles or ulcers.

C) INCORRECT:

Positive findings on gonococcal culture can support the diagnosis of PID. However, PID is primarily a clinical diagnosis, and an endocervical swab has already been obtained for nucleic acid amplification testing. Another step in management is more appropriate at this time.

D) INCORRECT:

Colposcopy is used as a screening method for premalignant and malignant cervical lesions, usually after an abnormal Pap smear. It is also indicated in cases of postcoital bleeding. Neither of these indications is present in this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

For patients in their third decade of life, a Pap smear is routinely recommended every 3 years. This patient had a normal Pap smear 5 months ago.

F) CORRECT:

PID is most commonly caused by infection with Chlamydia trachomatis and/or Neisseria gonorrhoeae as a result of unprotected sex, which increases the risk for other sexually transmitted infections (STIs). Therefore, all patients diagnosed with PID should undergo testing for other STIs, including HIV and syphilis.

Patients with PID should be treated with empiric antibiotic therapy that is effective against N. gonorrheae (ceftriaxone) and C. trachomatis (doxycycline) and also provides coverage against anaerobes (metronidazole).
questions.hint: Vaginal discharge in combination with uterine and adnexal tenderness suggests pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). PID is a clinical diagnosis; a positive test for cervical infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis supports the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the emergency department with a 5-day history of severe abdominal pain, cramping, nausea, and vomiting. She also has pain with urination. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She experienced a burning pain when she last had sexual intercourse 3 days ago. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 5 days. Her last menstrual period was 3 weeks ago. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants. Pelvic examination shows cervical motion tenderness and purulent cervical discharge. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 15,000/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 100 mm/h. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis can also manifest with fever, nausea, dysuria, and abdominal or pelvic pain. However, patients with pyelonephritis typically also have unilateral flank pain and costovertebral angle tenderness. Furthermore, this patient's other features (e.g., cervical motion tenderness, purulent vaginal discharge, dyspareunia) are not consistent with pyelonephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting are common findings in ectopic pregnancy. Cervical motion tenderness, uterine tenderness, or adnexal tenderness may also be present. However, these symptoms usually appear 4–6 weeks after the last normal menstrual period, whereas this patient's last period was just 3 weeks ago. Moreover, the purulent cervical discharge seen on examination of this patient is not a characteristic finding.

C) INCORRECT:

An ovarian cyst rupture causes sudden, unilateral lower abdominal pain and typically occurs during periods of physical activity (e.g., exercise, sexual intercourse). This patient's pain is bilateral, and although she had dyspareunia during sexual intercourse 3 days ago, her symptoms began 2 days prior to that. Moreover, the pain of a ruptured ovarian cyst is usually not associated with signs of infection such as fever or purulent discharge

D) INCORRECT:

Important findings in appendicitis include fever, abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, leukocytosis, and elevated ESR, which are all present in this patient. However, purulent cervical discharge and cervical motion tenderness indicate infection of the reproductive organs rather than the appendix.

E) INCORRECT:

This patient's lower abdominal pain, purulent discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria are all characteristic of vulvovaginitis. However, the pelvic examination shows cervical motion tenderness, which is characteristic of inflammation of the upper reproductive tract rather than the vulva or vagina. She also has symptoms that are generally more severe than those caused by vulvovaginitis (e.g., severe pain, fever).

F) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with dysuria and lower abdominal pain, both of which are symptoms of cystitis. However, cystitis does not typically manifest with cervical motion tenderness or vaginal discharge, although gross hematuria may be present. In addition, the pain of cystitis tends to be localized suprapubically rather than in both lower abdominal quadrants.

G) CORRECT:

This patient presents with characteristic findings of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), i.e., lower abdominal pain (typically bilateral), cervical motion tenderness, and purulent vaginal discharge. Other manifestations of PID include dyspareunia, dysuria, leukocytosis, and an elevated ESR, all of which are seen here. PID is a clinical diagnosis.

Empiric antibiotic therapy that covers Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and anaerobes should be initiated immediately in patients with suspected PID to prevent complications (e.g., infertility due to fallopian tube damage). Obtaining vaginal and/or cervical swabs for nucleic acid amplification tests and/or culture for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis is recommended for all patients with suspected PID to identify pathogens and adjust antibiotic therapy.
questions.hint: This patient's condition should be suspected in sexually active women of reproductive age, who present with lower abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, and purulent cervical discharge.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician for the evaluation of fertility. She has been unable to conceive for 1 year despite regular intercourse with her husband twice per week. Recent analysis of her husband's semen showed a normal sperm count. Two years ago, she had an episode of a febrile illness with lower abdominal pain, which resolved under treatment with a medication she cannot recall. Menarche occurred at the age of 12 years, and menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4 to 5 days. Before her marriage, she was sexually active with 4 male partners and used a combined oral contraceptive pill with estrogen and progesterone consistently, in addition to barrier protection inconsistently. One year ago, she stopped using the oral contraceptive pill to try and conceive. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's infertility?

choices.text: Long-term use of the oral contraceptive pill

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) may present with failure to conceive due to absent or infrequent ovulation. Key features of PCOS include hyperandrogenism, ovulatory dysfunction (i.e., amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea), and obesity. Although this patient is obese (BMI 31 kg/m2), she has regular menstrual cycles and no clinical features of hyperandrogenism, such as hirsutism or acne. Therefore, it is unlikely that she has PCOS.

B) INCORRECT:

Long-term use of the oral contraceptive pill has no effect on fertility. Studies have shown that pregnancy rates following cessation of oral contraceptives, contraceptive implants, monthly contraceptive injections, copper intrauterine devices, and/or levonorgestrel intrauterine systems are similar to those reported following discontinuation of barrier methods or use of no contraceptive method.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis, resulting in pelvic inflammation and uterine adhesions, is one of the most common causes of infertility in women between 20–40 years of age. However, endometriosis commonly manifests with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding, nonspecific abdominal or pelvic pain, and is rarely asymptomatic. This patient does not have any of the clinical features associated with endometriosis, making it an unlikely cause of her infertility.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) commonly manifests with amenorrhea or irregular menstrual cycles. This condition can also manifest with symptoms of menopause, such as vaginal dryness, hot flashes, or mood disturbances. This patient has regular menstrual cycles and does not have any symptoms of menopause, making POI an unlikely cause of her infertility.

E) CORRECT:

Infertility following PID is a result of tubal scarring (due to salpingitis) with consequent loss of ciliary action and tubal occlusion. The risk of infertility increases with the number of episodes of PID and is around 12%, 25%, and 50% after one, two, and three episodes of PID, respectively. This patient needs further testing (e.g., hysterosalpingogram) for the evaluation of her fallopian tubes and the degree of damage. She may also require either surgery or in vitro fertilization to restore fertility.

Other complications associated with PID include tuboovarian abscess, pelvic peritonitis, sepsis, Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, and ectopic pregnancy.
Image Description:

Hysterosalpingogram

The tube is occluded at the isthmic portion of the fallopian tubes on both sides (arrows). Size and shape of the uterine cavity are inconspicuous.

These findings are consistent with bilateral tubal blockage.

F) INCORRECT:

Cervical insufficiency (CI) is the inability of the cervix to retain a pregnancy in the second trimester in the absence of labor, contractions or any other underlying pathologies (e.g., infection, bleeding, premature rupture of membranes). While cervical insufficiency may prevent women from carrying pregnancies to term, CI does not affect a woman's ability to conceive.
questions.hint: This woman previously engaged in high-risk sexual behavior (inconsistent use of barrier protection) and had an episode of lower abdominal pain and febrile illness. This suggests an underlying diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 14 weeks' gestation, comes to the physician with a 3-day history of abnormal vaginal discharge. She has not had fever, chills, or abdominal pain. Her initial prenatal examination at 10 weeks' gestation showed no abnormalities. The patient has no history of serious illness. Her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She is sexually active with one male partner and they do not use condoms. Vital signs are within normal limits. Pelvic examination shows an inflamed and friable cervix. There is a mucopurulent, malodorous discharge from the cervical os. There is no uterine or cervical motion tenderness. Vaginal pH measurement shows a pH of 4.3. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Wet mount preparation of vaginal smear can be used to detect flagellated protozoa characteristic of trichomoniasis and clue cells characteristic of bacterial vaginosis (BV). These conditions can cause malodorous vaginal discharge but typically result in an elevated vaginal pH (pH > 4.5). In addition, isolated cervicitis is not a typical manifestation of either of these conditions. A wet mount preparation is unreliable in diagnosing the most common infectious causes of cervicitis because these infections only cause the nonspecific finding of a high leukocyte number on the wet mount.

B) INCORRECT:

The amine test (whiff test) is used to diagnose bacterial vaginosis (BV), which can cause malodorous vaginal discharge. However, BV typically manifests with an elevated vaginal pH (pH > 4.5) and a gray or milky rather than mucopurulent discharge. Isolated cervicitis makes BV highly unlikely. The amine test does not evaluate for the most common infectious causes of cervicitis.

C) INCORRECT:

Urine analysis and culture would be the most appropriate initial step if a urinary tract infection (UTI) was suspected. This patient presents with cervicitis and does not report features of a UTI (e.g., dysuria, urgency, frequency, suprapubic pain).

D) CORRECT:

A nucleic acid amplification test (NAAT) is the preferred modality for diagnosing Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae infections, which are the most common causes of cervicitis. NAAT can also diagnose certain uncommon causes of acute cervicitis such as trichomoniasis. Patients with confirmed gonorrhea, chlamydia, or trichomoniasis should also be screened for HIV and syphilis. Chlamydia and gonorrhea testing is indicated during the initial prenatal visit (at approx. 10 weeks' gestation) in all patients < 25 years of age and in patients ≥ 25 years of age with risk factors for sexually transmitted infections.

See “Differential diagnoses of infectious causes of vaginal discharge” table.

E) INCORRECT:

A potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation is used to diagnose vulvovaginal candidiasis, which can manifest with vaginal discharge and a normal vaginal pH of 4.0–4.5. The discharge, however, is usually odorless and white, crumbly, and sticky rather than mucopurulent. In addition, features of inflammatory vaginitis (e.g., intense pruritus, vaginal burning, dyspareunia, vulvar and vaginal erythema) are typically present. Isolated cervicitis is not typical of vulvovaginal candidiasis. A KOH preparation does not evaluate for the most common infectious causes of cervicitis.
questions.hint: An inflamed, friable cervix with a mucopurulent discharge from the cervical os in a sexually active patient suggests cervicitis.

questions.text: A 32-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the physician because of 2 weeks of postcoital pain and blood-tinged vaginal discharge. She has been sexually active with one male partner for the past 3 months. They do not use condoms. Her only medication is a combined oral contraceptive that she has been taking for the past 2 years. She states that she takes the medication fairly consistently, but may forget a pill 2–3 days per month. One year ago, her Pap smear was normal. She has not received the HPV vaccine. Vital signs are within normal limits. The cervix is tender to motion on bimanual exam. There is bleeding when the cervix is touched with a cotton swab during speculum exam. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The main clinical features of endometriosis include chronic pelvic pain that worsens just before menstruation, dysmenorrhea, premenstrual, or postmenstrual bleeding, and during sexual intercourse (dyspareunia). While endometriosis can spread to the cervix and cause postcoital bleeding, it is associated with dysmenorrhea and menstrual cycle irregularities and, therefore, unlikely in this case.

B) INCORRECT:

Trauma to the cervix can be due to several causes, including insertion of tampons or cervical caps, diaphragms or intrauterine devices, and vigorous sexual intercourse. While cervix trauma also manifests with vaginal bleeding and is often painful, it is not the most common cause of this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

An ectopic pregnancy occurs when a fertilized egg attaches outside of the uterus, most commonly in the fallopian tubes. Lower abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, and cervical motion tenderness are common symptoms. Although this patient does not take her oral contraceptive consistently and could be pregnant, vaginal discharge and postcoital pain are indicative of a different cause.

D) INCORRECT:

Uterine leiomyomas are benign neoplasms often seen in women with a history of nulliparity and early menarche. Common clinical features include dysmenorrhea, menorrhagia, dyspareunia, and palpable, irregular uterine enlargement. In the absence of menstrual cycle irregularities and uterine enlargement, which would have been apparent on physical examination, uterine leiomyomas can be ruled out.

E) INCORRECT:

Breakthrough bleeding is the term for bleeding that occurs mid-cycle, and most commonly occurs in women who use combined oral contraceptives, particularly within the first few months after starting treatment. Since this patient occasionally forgets to take her contraceptive medication, breakthrough bleeding is possible. However, breakthrough bleeding is usually painless and not accompanied by pathological findings on physical examination.

F) INCORRECT:

Although early uterine pregnancy may manifest with slight vaginal bleeding, other typical features (e.g., amenorrhea, nausea/vomiting, breast enlargement, fatigue) are absent in this patient. She also lacks pregnancy-typical changes of the cervix on physical examination, including initial softening, increased blood flow, and production of a clear, viscous mucus. Friability and easy bleeding of the cervix are indicative of a different underlying condition.

G) INCORRECT:

Cervical dysplasia, also referred to as cervical intraepithelial neoplasia, is a precursor to cervical cancer and is strongly associated with HPV infections. Early disease stages are usually asymptomatic, while more advanced disease manifests with abnormal vaginal bleeding (e.g., postcoital bleeding), blood-stained or purulent discharge, and hydronephrosis if tumor growth compresses the ureters. While this patient has an increased risk of contracting HPV (no HPV vaccination, unprotected intercourse with a new partner), the development of cervical dysplasia within a year of her last normal Pap smear is unlikely.

H) CORRECT:

Infection with Chlamydia trachomatis and/or Neisseria gonorrhoeae is the most common cause of cervicitis. Clinical features of this condition include purulent and/or bloody vaginal discharge, dyspareunia, and postcoital bleeding. Bimanual examination typically shows cervical motion tenderness, while pelvic examination reveals an erythematous, edematous, friable cervix that bleeds upon contact. Cervicitis typically manifests without fever or abdominal pain (as opposed to infections with upper reproductive tract involvement such as pelvic inflammatory disease). This patient's history and increased risk of sexually transmitted infections (unprotected intercourse, new sexual partner) make cervicitis due to a chlamydial infection the most likely diagnosis.
Image Description:

Colposcopy view of the ectocervix

The ectocervix is erythematous and there is purulent discharge from the external os.
questions.hint: The cervical motion tenderness and friable cervix in this patient suggest cervicitis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old nulligravid patient comes to the physician for evaluation of infertility. She has been unable to conceive for 14 months. One year ago, she stopped taking the oral contraceptive pill, which she had been using since she was 17. Her husband's semen analysis was normal. Four years ago, she had an episode of pelvic tenderness and vaginal discharge that resolved without treatment. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals. Before her marriage, she was sexually active with 5 male partners and used condoms inconsistently. She is 169 cm (5 ft 6 in) tall and weighs 86 kg (190 lb); BMI is 31.6 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's infertility?

choices.text: Adverse effect of oral contraceptive pill

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Insulin resistance is involved in the pathogenesis of polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS), which can result in failure to conceive due to absent or infrequent ovulation. While this patient's obesity (BMI of 31.6 kg/m2) is a risk factor for PCOS, she has regular menstrual cycles and no clinical features of hyperandrogenism, e.g., hirsutism or acne, that would raise suspicion for PCOS.

B) CORRECT:

Infertility due to PID is a result of tubal scarring, which causes tubal occlusion and loss of ciliary action. The risk of infertility increases with each episode of PID. Other complications of PID include tuboovarian abscess, pelvic peritonitis, sepsis, Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, and ectopic pregnancy. Symptomatic PID typically manifests with bilateral lower abdominal pain or tenderness, and inflammation of the genital tract, but symptoms vary and may be very subtle or absent. PID should be treated with empiric antibiotic therapy that is effective against the most common causative pathogens, i.e., Neisseria gonorrhoeae (ceftriaxone) and Chlamydia trachomatis (doxycycline), and that also covers anaerobes (metronidazole).

Further testing (e.g., hysterosalpingogram) is required to evaluate this patient for potential damage to the fallopian tubes. Surgery or in vitro fertilization may also be necessary to restore fertility.

C) INCORRECT:

Long-term use of the oral contraceptive pill has no effect on fertility. Studies have shown that pregnancy rates following cessation of oral contraceptives, contraceptive implants, monthly contraceptive injections, copper IUDs, and/or levonorgestrel intrauterine systems (LNG-IUS) are similar to those reported following discontinuation of barrier methods or use of no contraceptive method.

D) INCORRECT:

Ectopic endometrial tissue causes endometriosis, which can lead to adhesions in the uterus and/or fallopian tubes that cause infertility in young women. The typical presentation of endometriosis involves dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, and postcoital bleeding, none of which is mentioned in this patient. PID is not a risk factor for development of endometriosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) commonly manifests as amenorrhea or irregular menstrual cycles. This condition can also manifest with symptoms of menopause, e.g., vaginal dryness, hot flashes, and mood disturbances. This patient has regular menstrual cycles and does not show any symptoms of menopause, making POI an unlikely cause of her infertility.
questions.hint: This patient has previously engaged in high-risk sexual behavior. This puts her at risk for sexually transmitted infections and pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), which was the likely cause of her episode of pelvic tenderness and vaginal discharge.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 6-day history of progressive lower abdominal pain, nausea, and decreased appetite. She also noticed mild pain with urination and a mild fever for the past 2 days. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 1 week. Her last menstrual period was 10 days ago. She has no history of serious illness or surgery and takes no medications. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and sometimes uses condoms for contraception. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 108/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants with mild guarding. There is bloody discharge from the cervix. Bimanual examination shows cervical motion tenderness and a tender right adnexal mass. Her hematocrit is 34%, leukocyte count is 18,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 80 mm/h. Pelvic ultrasonography shows a normal uterus with a thick-walled, multiloculated right adnexal mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An appendiceal abscess can develop in patients with an untreated perforated appendix and is usually characterized by high-grade fever, a tender RLQ mass, and an increase in inflammatory markers. A thick-walled, multiloculated right adnexal mass on ultrasonography could also be observed in a patient with an appendiceal abscess due to the proximity of the appendix and uterine adnexa. However, cervical tenderness and bloody discharge would not be expected.

B) CORRECT:

Tuboovarian abscess is a severe complication of PID characterized by the development of an inflammatory mass confined to the fallopian tubes and/or ovaries, which appears as a tender adnexal mass on physical examination. Ultrasonography is the best test for the diagnosis of a tuboovarian abscess and typically shows a thick-walled, multiloculated cystic mass in the area of the adnexa, as observed in this patient. Tuboovarian abscess is a life-threatening condition that can be complicated by severe sepsis or spread to the adjacent organs (e.g., bladder, bowel) and should, therefore, be managed promptly. Treatment usually consists of broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotic therapy and, in severe cases, surgical exploration.

Other complications of PID include ectopic pregnancy, infertility, and Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cancer can, in later stages, manifest with abdominal pain, nausea, and vaginal bleeding. However, this condition typically affects postmenopausal women (> 55 years of age) and ultrasonography would show solid components of the adnexal mass. This patient's signs of infection (e.g., fever, leukocytosis), age, and subacute presentation make PID a much more likely diagnosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Ovarian torsion typically manifests with the sudden onset of unilateral lower abdominal pain, nausea, and a palpable adnexal mass. If torsion occurs as a complication of an ovarian cyst, ultrasonography may show evidence of an adnexal mass. However, further ultrasonographic findings (e.g., an enlarged, edematous ovary with decreased blood flow, a twisted vascular pedicle) would be expected. Furthermore, this patient's symptoms worsened gradually over 6 days and laboratory studies show signs of inflammation, neither of which can be explained by ovarian torsion.

E) INCORRECT:

Ectopic pregnancy is a possible long-term complication of PID and manifests with lower abdominal pain, nausea, anorexia, and bloody cervical discharge. Patients with PID who do not use consistent protection during sexual intercourse are at risk of ectopic pregnancy. However, this patient's last period was 10 days ago, while symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy usually develop at least 6–8 weeks after the last menstrual period. In addition, pelvic ultrasonography showed a thick-walled, multiloculated right adnexal mass rather than typical signs of ectopic pregnancy (e.g., a tubal ring sign).
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (transabdominal; transverse plane) of a 31-year-old woman with history of abdominal pain, presyncope, and a positive pregnancy test

A thick-walled echogenic ring lesion (blue overlay) is seen in the right adnexa, adjacent to which there is trace free fluid (yellow overlay). No uterine masses were identified and an intrauterine gestation was not detected. The adnexal lesion proved to represent a gestational sac of an ectopic pregnancy.

An adnexal mass separate from the ovary is a common presentation of ectopic pregnancy. The diagnosis becomes more specific if a yolk sac or living embryo is detected within the mass. Color Doppler of an ectopic pregnancy may show prominent peripheral vascularity (ring of fire sign), which can similarly occur with a corpus luteum cyst.

Green overlay: uterine wall
Red overlay: endometrial stripe
IIA: internal iliac artery
IIV: internal illiac vein
O: ovary

F) INCORRECT:

An ovarian cyst rupture typically occurs in women of reproductive age after an episode of vigorous activity or sexual intercourse and is characterized by sudden-onset lower abdominal pain, nausea, possible vaginal bleeding, and an adnexal mass on palpation in patients with large cysts. Although all of these symptoms are observed in this patient, they have developed gradually over 6 days, were not triggered by an event, and were accompanied by an increase in inflammatory markers, which is inconsistent with an ovarian cyst rupture. Furthermore, ultrasonography would most likely show free liquid in the pouch of Douglas in addition to an adnexal cystic mass.
questions.hint: This patient has multiple sexual partners and does not use condoms consistently. Combined with her symptoms (e.g., fever, vaginal discharge, pain with urination), examination findings (e.g., cervical motion tenderness, bloody cervical discharge), and positive inflammatory markers on laboratory studies (leukocytosis, increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate), this points to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman reports low-grade fevers and diffuse lower-abdominal pain that is worsened by sexual intercourse. She recently became sexually active with a new male partner and is taking oral contraceptives for birth control. She states that she does not experience any other symptoms and says that her last menstrual period, 2 weeks ago, was normal.
She has a temperature of 38.4°C and otherwise normal vital signs. She has tenderness of the abdomen over the bilateral lower quadrants and cervical-motion tenderness on bimanual examination. A urine pregnancy test is negative; a wet mount of vaginal secretions is unremarkable.
In addition to doxycycline and metronidazole, which one of the following agents is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an acute infection of the structures of the female upper genital tract. A finding of adnexal or cervical-motion tenderness is alone sufficient to establish the clinical diagnosis. Supportive diagnostic findings, alone or in combination, include fever >38.3°C, abnormal cervical or vaginal discharge, microscopic evidence of abundant numbers of leukocytes on wet mount, an elevated C-reactive protein level, and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Nonpregnant patients with mild-to-moderate infection (i.e., those who lack severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or high fever) can be managed in the outpatient setting.

Recommendations for empiric treatment regimens for PID have long included coverage for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, typically with doxycycline in combination with ceftriaxone, cefoxitin, or a parenteral third-generation cephalosporin. However, the latest treatment guidelines also recommend adding metronidazole for coverage of anaerobes. Thus, the combination of oral doxycycline, intramuscular ceftriaxone, and oral metronidazole is an appropriate choice for this patient.

Patients with PID should also be counseled about safe-sex practices and the need for partner evaluation.

Key learning point: Empiric treatment for mild-to-moderate pelvic inflammatory disease in the outpatient setting consists of doxycycline, metronidazole, and a cephalosporin, most commonly ceftriaxone or cefoxitin.

B) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones are no longer recommended, given that N. gonorrhoeae is increasingly resistant to them.

C) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline plus ampicillin-sulbactam should be reserved as an alternate treatment, given limited efficacy data to support its use in this clinical context. Furthermore, ampicillin-sulbactam requires intravenous administration, which is generally not desirable for outpatient treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous clindamycin — in conjunction with gentamicin — can be used for hospitalized or penicillin-allergic patients.

E) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is an alternative treatment for chlamydia, but the doxycycline in this patient’s regimen already treats chlamydia, and azithromycin should not be used in place of a cephalosporin.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old nulligravid woman reports a 72-hour history of vaginal discharge and dysuria. She has no significant medical or gynecologic history. She has a new male sexual partner. She uses oral contraceptives and intermittently uses condoms.
On examination, her blood pressure is 126/78 mm Hg, her heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and her temperature is 37.9°C. There is mucopurulent discharge at the cervical os. She reports pain during manipulation of the cervix on bimanual examination. No adnexal masses are palpated. A wet mount is negative for yeast, clue cells, and Trichomonas vaginalis, but an abundance of leukocytes is present. A pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following treatment approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: One dose of oral cefixime followed by a 10-day course of oral doxycycline
One dose of oral cefixime followed by a 10-day course of oral metronidazole
One dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone followed by a 14-day course of oral doxycycline and metronidazole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral cefixime is not recommended because recent studies have shown that Neisseria gonorrhoeae has developed increasing resistance to oral cephalosporins.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral levofloxacin alone is not recommended because of the risk for fluoroquinolone-resistant N. gonorrhoeae.

C) INCORRECT:

Parenteral therapy, such as with cefoxitin and doxycycline, would be recommended for patients with severe nausea and vomiting, high fever, tubo-ovarian abscess, pregnancy, or difficulty adhering to outpatient therapy. Cefoxitin plus vancomycin is not a recommended regimen for PID.

D) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole can be used in combination with a second- or third-generation cephalosporin and doxycycline, but it should not be used in place of doxycycline.

E) CORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is clinically diagnosed by mucopurulent discharge and cervical motion tenderness on examination. Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis are typical causative organisms, as are anaerobes. Outpatient antibiotic treatment can be considered for patients with mild to moderately severe PID. A recommended treatment is one dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone, followed by a 14-day course of both oral doxycycline and metronidazole.

Patients with PID should be followed closely and should also be counseled about safe-sex practices and the need for partner evaluation.

Key learning point: Mild to moderately severe pelvic inflammatory disease is treated with one dose of a second- or third-generation cephalosporin administered intramuscularly, followed by both oral doxycycline and metronidazole for 2 weeks.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old female college student reports low-grade fevers and diffuse lower-abdominal pain that is worsened by sexual intercourse. She recently became sexually active with a new male partner and is taking oral contraceptives for birth control. She states that she does not experience any other symptoms and says that her last menstrual period, 2 weeks ago, was normal.
She has a temperature of 38.4°C and otherwise normal vital signs. She has tenderness of the abdomen over the bilateral lower quadrants and cervical-motion tenderness on bimanual examination. A urine pregnancy test is negative; a wet mount of vaginal secretions is unremarkable.
In addition to doxycycline and metronidazole, which one of the following agents is most appropriate for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intravenous clindamycin — in conjunction with gentamicin — can be used for hospitalized or penicillin-allergic patients.

B) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin is an alternative treatment for chlamydia, but the doxycycline in this patient’s regimen already treats chlamydia, and azithromycin should not be used in place of a cephalosporin.

C) CORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is an acute infection of the structures of the female upper genital tract. A finding of adnexal or cervical-motion tenderness is alone sufficient to establish the clinical diagnosis. Supportive diagnostic findings, alone or in combination, include fever >38.3°C, abnormal cervical or vaginal discharge, microscopic evidence of abundant numbers of leukocytes on wet mount, an elevated C-reactive protein level, and an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Nonpregnant patients with mild-to-moderate infection (i.e., those who lack severe abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, or high fever) can be managed in the outpatient setting.

Recommendations for empiric treatment regimens for PID have long included coverage for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, typically with doxycycline in combination with ceftriaxone, cefoxitin, or a parenteral third-generation cephalosporin. However, the latest treatment guidelines also recommend adding metronidazole for coverage of anaerobes. Thus, the combination of oral doxycycline, intramuscular ceftriaxone, and oral metronidazole is an appropriate choice for this patient.

Patients with PID should also be counseled about safe-sex practices and the need for partner evaluation.

Key learning point: Empiric treatment for mild-to-moderate pelvic inflammatory disease in the outpatient setting consists of doxycycline, metronidazole, and a cephalosporin, most commonly ceftriaxone or cefoxitin.

D) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline plus ampicillin-sulbactam should be reserved as an alternate treatment, given limited efficacy data to support its use in this clinical context. Furthermore, ampicillin-sulbactam requires intravenous administration, which is generally not desirable for outpatient treatment.

E) INCORRECT:

Fluoroquinolones are no longer recommended, given that N. gonorrhoeae is increasingly resistant to them.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old female college student reports a 72-hour history of vaginal discharge and dysuria. She has no significant medical or gynecologic history. She has a new male sexual partner. She uses oral contraceptives and intermittently uses condoms.
On examination, her blood pressure is 126/78 mm Hg, her heart rate is 90 beats per minute, and her temperature is 37.9°C. There is mucopurulent discharge at the cervical os. She reports pain during manipulation of the cervix on bimanual examination. No adnexal masses are palpated.
A wet mount is negative for yeast, clue cells, and Trichomonas vaginalis, but an abundance of leukocytes is present. A pregnancy test is negative.
Which one of the following treatment approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: One dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone followed by a 14-day course of oral doxycycline and metronidazole
One dose of oral cefixime followed by a 10-day course of oral doxycycline
One dose of oral cefixime followed by a 10-day course of oral metronidazole

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) is clinically diagnosed by mucopurulent discharge and cervical motion tenderness on examination. Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis are typical causative organisms, as are anaerobes. Outpatient antibiotic treatment can be considered for patients with mild to moderately severe PID. A recommended treatment is one dose of intramuscular ceftriaxone, followed by a 14-day course of both oral doxycycline and metronidazole.

Patients with PID should be followed closely and counseled to expect improvement within 3 days. They should also be counseled about safe-sex practices and the need for their partners to be evaluated and possibly treated.

Key learning point: Mild to moderately severe pelvic inflammatory disease is treated with one dose of a second- or third-generation cephalosporin administered intramuscularly, followed by both oral doxycycline and metronidazole for 2 weeks.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral cefixime is not recommended because recent studies have shown that N. gonorrhoeae has developed increasing resistance to oral cephalosporins.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral cefixime is not recommended because recent studies have shown that N. gonorrhoeae has developed increasing resistance to oral cephalosporins. Metronidazole can be used in combination with a second- or third-generation cephalosporin and doxycycline, but it should not be used in place of doxycycline.

D) INCORRECT:

Oral levofloxacin alone is not recommended because of the risk for fluoroquinolone-resistant N. gonorrhoeae.

E) INCORRECT:

Parenteral therapy, such as with cefoxitin and doxycycline, would be recommended for patients with severe nausea and vomiting, high fever, tubo-ovarian abscess, pregnancy, or difficulty adhering to outpatient therapy. Cefoxitin plus vancomycin is not a recommended regimen for PID.

questions.text: A 27-year-old nulligravid woman comes to the office for the evaluation of fertility. She has been unable to conceive for 1 year despite regular intercourse with her husband twice per week. Recent analysis of her husband's semen showed a normal sperm count. Two years ago, she had an episode of a febrile illness with lower abdominal pain, which resolved under treatment with a medication she cannot recall. Menses occur at regular 28-day intervals and last 4 to 5 days. Before her marriage, she used a combined oral contraceptive pill with estrogen and progesterone consistently, in addition to barrier protection inconsistently. One year ago, she stopped using the oral contraceptive pill to try and conceive. She is 165 cm (5 ft 5 in) tall and weighs 84 kg (185 lb); BMI is 31 kg/m2. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this patient's infertility?

choices.text: Long-term use of the oral contraceptive pill

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) may present with failure to conceive due to absent or infrequent ovulation. Key features of PCOS include hyperandrogenism, ovulatory dysfunction (i.e., amenorrhea or oligomenorrhea), and obesity. Although this patient is obese (BMI 31 kg/m2), she has regular menstrual cycles and no clinical features of hyperandrogenism, such as hirsutism or acne. Therefore, it is unlikely that she has PCOS.

B) INCORRECT:

Long-term use of the oral contraceptive pill has no effect on fertility. Studies have shown that pregnancy rates following cessation of oral contraceptives, contraceptive implants, monthly contraceptive injections, copper intrauterine devices, and/or levonorgestrel intrauterine systems are similar to those reported following discontinuation of barrier methods or use of no contraceptive method.

C) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis, resulting in pelvic inflammation and uterine adhesions, is one of the most common causes of infertility in women between 20–40 years of age. However, endometriosis commonly manifests with dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, postcoital bleeding, nonspecific abdominal or pelvic pain, and is rarely asymptomatic. This patient does not have any of the clinical features associated with endometriosis, making it an unlikely cause of her infertility.

D) INCORRECT:

Primary ovarian insufficiency (POI) commonly manifests with amenorrhea or irregular menstrual cycles. This condition can also manifest with symptoms of menopause, such as vaginal dryness, hot flashes, or mood disturbances. This patient has regular menstrual cycles and does not have any symptoms of menopause, making POI an unlikely cause of her infertility.

E) CORRECT:

Infertility following PID is a result of tubal scarring (due to salpingitis) with consequent loss of ciliary action and tubal occlusion. The risk of infertility increases with the number of episodes of PID and is around 12%, 25%, and 50% after one, two, and three episodes of PID, respectively. This patient needs further testing (e.g., hysterosalpingogram) for the evaluation of her fallopian tubes and the degree of damage. She may also require either surgery or in vitro fertilization to restore fertility.

Other complications associated with PID include tuboovarian abscess, pelvic peritonitis, sepsis, Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, and ectopic pregnancy.
Image Description:

Hysterosalpingogram

The tube is occluded at the isthmic portion of the fallopian tubes on both sides (arrows). Size and shape of the uterine cavity are inconspicuous.

These findings are consistent with bilateral tubal blockage.
questions.hint: This woman previously engaged in high-risk sexual behavior (inconsistent use of barrier protection) and had an episode of lower abdominal pain and febrile illness. This suggests an underlying diagnosis of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain and dysuria. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections that have resolved with antibiotic treatment. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they do not use condoms. She had mild pain during her last sexual intercourse 1 week ago. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows lower abdominal tenderness and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a small amount of purulent vaginal discharge. Bimanual examination shows uterine and cervical motion tenderness. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: Intramuscular ceftriaxone, oral doxycycline, and oral metronidazole

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is effective against infection with anaerobic protozoa and should be part of the empiric antibiotic regimen for PID. Metronidazole alone, however, does not cover the most typical causative pathogens of PID, i.e., N. gonorrhea and C. trachomatis.

B) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of PID. Oral azithromycin can be used to treat infection with Chlamydia trachomatis, which is one of the most common causative organisms of PID, but another regimen is preferred. Furthermore, PID should also be treated with antibiotics that provide anaerobic coverage.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral administration of levofloxacin and metronidazole is suitable for treating PID in patients with cephalosporin allergies. This patient has no history of allergy; a different regimen is preferred.

D) CORRECT:

PID is a clinical diagnosis that is made in sexually active individuals with abdominal and/or pelvic pain if there is no other suspected cause and pelvic examination shows adnexal, uterine, and/or cervical motion tenderness. Patients with PID should be treated with empiric antibiotic therapy that targets the most common causative pathogens, i.e., Neisseria gonorrhoeae (ceftriaxone) and Chlamydia trachomatis (doxycycline), and also covers anaerobes (metronidazole). Outpatient care is preferred for uncomplicated PID. Patients with complicating factors (e.g., pregnancy, suspected tuboovarian abscess, high fever) should be hospitalized and treated with intravenous antibiotics.

Patients with PID should be advised to abstain from sexual activity until antibiotic therapy has been completed, symptoms have resolved, and sexual partners have been treated. All patients diagnosed with PID should also undergo testing for other sexually transmitted infections, including HIV and syphilis.

E) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is typically recommended for the treatment of PID because it covers N. gonorrhoeae, one of the most common causative pathogens. However, empiric antibiotic treatment for PID should also provide coverage for Chlamydia trachomatis, another common causative pathogen, and anaerobes. Ceftriaxone therapy alone is inappropriate.
questions.hint: The onset of lower abdominal pain, dysuria, dyspareunia, and purulent vaginal discharge, in conjunction with uterine and cervical motion tenderness in a sexually active woman, is highly suggestive of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to the emergency department with a 6-day history of progressive lower abdominal pain, nausea, and decreased appetite. She also noticed mild pain with urination and a mild fever for the past 2 days. Menses occur at regular 30-day intervals and last 1 week. Her last menstrual period was 10 days ago. She is sexually active with multiple male partners and usually uses condoms for contraception. She appears ill. Her temperature is 39.2°C (102.5°F). Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants with mild guarding. There is bloody discharge from the cervix. Bimanual examination shows cervical motion tenderness and a tender right adnexal mass. Her hematocrit is 34%, leukocyte count is 18,000/mm3, and erythrocyte sedimentation rate is 80 mm/h. Pelvic ultrasonography shows a normal uterus with a thick-walled, multiloculated right adnexal mass. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Tuboovarian abscess is a severe complication of PID characterized by the development of an inflammatory mass confined to the fallopian tubes and/or ovaries, which appears as a tender adnexal mass on physical examination. Ultrasonography is the best test for the diagnosis of a tuboovarian abscess and typically shows a thick-walled, multiloculated cystic mass in the area of the adnexa, as observed in this patient. Tuboovarian abscess is a life-threatening condition that can be complicated by severe sepsis or spread to the adjacent organs (e.g., bladder, bowel) and should, therefore, be managed promptly. Treatment usually consists of broad-spectrum intravenous antibiotic therapy and, in severe cases, surgical exploration.

Other complications of PID include ectopic pregnancy, infertility, and Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

Ovarian cancer can, in later stages, manifest with abdominal pain, nausea, and vaginal bleeding. However, this condition typically affects postmenopausal women (> 55 years of age) and ultrasonography would show solid components of the adnexal mass. This patient's signs of infection (e.g., fever, leukocytosis), age, and subacute presentation make PID a much more likely diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

Ovarian torsion typically manifests with the sudden onset of unilateral lower abdominal pain, nausea, and a palpable adnexal mass. If torsion occurs as a complication of an ovarian cyst, ultrasonography may show evidence of an adnexal mass. However, further ultrasonographic findings (e.g., an enlarged, edematous ovary with decreased blood flow, a twisted vascular pedicle) would be expected. Furthermore, this patient's symptoms worsened gradually over 6 days and laboratory studies show signs of inflammation, neither of which can be explained by ovarian torsion.

D) INCORRECT:

Ectopic pregnancy is a possible long-term complication of PID and manifests with lower abdominal pain, nausea, anorexia, and bloody cervical discharge. Patients with PID who do not use consistent protection during sexual intercourse are at risk of ectopic pregnancy. However, this patient's last period was 10 days ago, while symptoms of an ectopic pregnancy usually develop at least 6–8 weeks after the last menstrual period. In addition, pelvic ultrasonography showed a thick-walled, multiloculated right adnexal mass rather than typical signs of ectopic pregnancy (e.g., a tubal ring sign).
Image Description:

Ultrasound pelvis (transabdominal; transverse plane) of a 31-year-old woman with history of abdominal pain, presyncope, and a positive pregnancy test

A thick-walled echogenic ring lesion (blue overlay) is seen in the right adnexa, adjacent to which there is trace free fluid (yellow overlay). No uterine masses were identified and an intrauterine gestation was not detected. The adnexal lesion proved to represent a gestational sac of an ectopic pregnancy.

An adnexal mass separate from the ovary is a common presentation of ectopic pregnancy. The diagnosis becomes more specific if a yolk sac or living embryo is detected within the mass. Color Doppler of an ectopic pregnancy may show prominent peripheral vascularity (ring of fire sign), which can similarly occur with a corpus luteum cyst.

Green overlay: uterine wall
Red overlay: endometrial stripe
IIA: internal iliac artery
IIV: internal illiac vein
O: ovary

E) INCORRECT:

An ovarian cyst rupture typically occurs in women of reproductive age after an episode of vigorous activity or sexual intercourse and is characterized by sudden-onset lower abdominal pain, nausea, possible vaginal bleeding, and an adnexal mass on palpation in patients with large cysts. Although all of these symptoms are observed in this patient, they have developed gradually over 6 days, were not triggered by an event, and were accompanied by an increase in inflammatory markers, which is inconsistent with an ovarian cyst rupture. Furthermore, ultrasonography would most likely show free liquid in the pouch of Douglas in addition to an adnexal cystic mass.
questions.hint: This patient has multiple sexual partners and does not necessarily use condoms consistently. Combined with her symptoms (e.g., fever, vaginal discharge, pain with urination), examination findings (e.g., cervical motion tenderness, bloody cervical discharge), and positive inflammatory markers on laboratory studies (leukocytosis, increased erythrocyte sedimentation rate), this points to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the emergency department with a 5-day history of severe abdominal pain, cramping, nausea, and vomiting. She also has pain with urination. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they use condoms inconsistently. She experienced a burning pain when she last had sexual intercourse 3 days ago. Her temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. Physical examination shows abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants. Pelvic examination shows cervical motion tenderness and purulent cervical discharge. Laboratory studies show a leukocyte count of 15,000/mm3 and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 100 mm/hr. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis can also manifest with fever, nausea, dysuria, and abdominal or pelvic pain. However, patients with pyelonephritis typically also have unilateral flank pain and costovertebral angle tenderness. Furthermore, this patient's other features (e.g., cervical motion tenderness, purulent vaginal discharge, dyspareunia) are not consistent with pyelonephritis.

B) INCORRECT:

An ovarian cyst rupture causes sudden, unilateral lower abdominal pain and typically occurs during periods of physical activity (e.g., exercise, sexual intercourse). This patient's pain is bilateral, and although she had dyspareunia during sexual intercourse 3 days ago, her symptoms began 2 days prior to that. Moreover, the pain of a ruptured ovarian cyst is usually not associated with signs of infection such as fever or purulent discharge

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's lower abdominal pain, purulent discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria are all characteristic of vulvovaginitis. However, the pelvic examination shows cervical motion tenderness, which is characteristic of inflammation of the upper reproductive tract rather than the vulva or vagina. She also has symptoms that are generally more severe than those caused by vulvovaginitis (e.g., severe pain, fever).

D) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with dysuria and lower abdominal pain, both of which are symptoms of cystitis. However, cystitis does not typically manifest with cervical motion tenderness or vaginal discharge, although gross hematuria may be present. In addition, the pain of cystitis tends to be localized suprapubically rather than in both lower abdominal quadrants.

E) CORRECT:

This patient presents with characteristic findings of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), i.e., lower abdominal pain (typically bilateral), cervical motion tenderness, and purulent vaginal discharge. Other manifestations of PID include dyspareunia, dysuria, leukocytosis, and an elevated ESR, all of which are seen here. PID is a clinical diagnosis.

Empiric antibiotic therapy that covers Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and anaerobes should be initiated immediately in patients with suspected PID to prevent complications (e.g., infertility due to fallopian tube damage). Obtaining vaginal and/or cervical swabs for nucleic acid amplification tests and/or culture for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis is recommended for all patients with suspected PID to identify pathogens and adjust antibiotic therapy.

Key learning point: Pelvic inflammatory disease is characterized by lower abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, and purulent cervical discharge in sexually active women, and requires prompt empiric antibiotic therapy to prevent reproductive complications.
questions.hint: This patient's condition should be suspected in sexually active women of reproductive age, who present with lower abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, and purulent cervical discharge.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old woman presents with a two-day history of lower abdominal pain and fever to the Outpatient Clinic. She reports a thick, yellow vaginal discharge and has had multiple recent sexual partners. She denies urinary symptoms. Pelvic examination reveals marked cervical motion tenderness and bilateral adnexal tenderness. Her pregnancy test is negative.


Heart rate
102/min


Temperature
38.6°C


Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis causes chronic, cyclic pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea, not acute inflammatory symptoms. The acute onset of pain, fever, tachycardia, and thick, yellow vaginal discharge are inconsistent with endometriosis. Cervical motion and bilateral adnexal tenderness suggest an infectious process rather than endometriosis.

B) CORRECT:

Acute salpingitis, a form of pelvic inflammatory disease, manifests with inflammation of the fallopian tubes due to ascending infection, often from sexually transmitted pathogens like Neisseria gonorrhoeae or Chlamydia trachomatis. The patient's age, history of multiple sexual partners, and symptoms such as lower abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, and bilateral adnexal tenderness suggest pelvic inflammatory disease. The thick, yellow vaginal discharge, fever, and tachycardia further support an infectious etiology. A negative pregnancy test excludes pregnancy-related complications, focusing the diagnosis on infectious causes. Pathogens migrate from the lower genital tract to the fallopian tubes, causing pain and systemic symptoms.

Key learning point: Acute salpingitis, a component of pelvic inflammatory disease, presents with lower abdominal pain, fever, purulent vaginal discharge, and adnexal tenderness.

C) INCORRECT:

A ruptured ovarian cyst can cause acute lower abdominal pain but lacks systemic infectious signs like fever and thick, yellow vaginal discharge. Cervical motion and bilateral adnexal tenderness indicate an infectious process. The patient's sexual history further suggests an infectious etiology over a mechanical process like cyst rupture.

D) INCORRECT:

Ectopic pregnancy typically presents with lower abdominal pain and adnexal tenderness, but a positive pregnancy test is expected due to trophoblastic activity. The negative human chorionic gonadotropin level and presence of fever and thick, yellow vaginal discharge suggest an infectious process rather than a gestational complication.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old nulligravida presents with three days of worsening lower abdominal pain, fever, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge. She had an intrauterine device placed two weeks ago. Her last menstrual period was one week ago, and she denies urinary changes. Examination reveals marked pain with cervical motion and no palpable adnexal masses.

Temperature
38.5°C

Which diagnosis best explains these findings?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Endometriosis usually presents with chronic, cyclical pelvic pain and dysmenorrhea, not acute systemic signs like fever. Foul-smelling discharge and cervical motion tenderness suggest an infectious process, not endometriosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Ovarian torsion presents with sudden, severe unilateral pain and often nausea or vomiting. The gradual symptom onset, fever, and foul-smelling discharge suggest an infectious process. Absence of a palpable adnexal mass also makes torsion less likely.

C) CORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) manifests with lower abdominal pain, fever, and foul-smelling vaginal discharge due to an ascending infection of the upper genital tract. The recent intrauterine device (IUD) placement increases susceptibility by facilitating pathogen passage from the lower genital tract. Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis are common causative organisms. Cervical motion tenderness indicates localized pelvic inflammation. The combination of these symptoms, along with the recent IUD insertion, supports the diagnosis of PID.

Key learning point: Pelvic inflammatory disease is a common complication following IUD insertion, presenting with abdominal pain and abnormal vaginal discharge.

D) INCORRECT:

Ectopic pregnancy typically presents with unilateral pelvic pain and vaginal spotting, not foul-smelling discharge. The recent menstrual period and fever further argue against this diagnosis. Additionally, recent intrauterine device placement reduces the likelihood of pregnancy.

questions.text:
A 23-year-old sexually active woman presents with four days of worsening lower abdominal pain radiating to the right upper quadrant. She reports increased vaginal discharge and mild mid-cycle spotting. Pelvic examination reveals cervical motion tenderness with minimal adnexal tenderness. Nucleic acid amplification testing confirms infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. Serum liver enzymes are mildly elevated. An abdominal ultrasound shows no gallbladder or biliary abnormalities.

Temperature
38.3°C

What is the most likely explanation for her right upper quadrant pain?

choices.text: Subhepatic abscess formed by hematogenous spread
Perihepatic inflammation due to ascending pelvic pathogens

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A subhepatic abscess would present with systemic signs of infection and radiologic evidence of a fluid collection, which are absent here. The patient's Chlamydia trachomatis infection and pelvic inflammatory disease suggest perihepatic inflammation rather than an abscess from hematogenous spread.

B) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis typically presents with urinary symptoms and flank pain, which are not reported in this patient. The absence of renal abnormalities on ultrasound and the presence of Chlamydia trachomatis infection with cervical motion tenderness suggest a pelvic inflammatory process rather than a renal infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Acute cholecystitis typically presents with right upper quadrant pain and ultrasound findings of gallstones or gallbladder wall thickening. However, this patient's ultrasound shows no gallbladder or biliary abnormalities. The presence of Chlamydia trachomatis infection and cervical motion tenderness indicates a pelvic inflammatory process rather than gallbladder pathology.

D) CORRECT:

Chlamydia trachomatis infection can ascend from the lower genital tract, leading to pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). In some cases, the infection extends to the perihepatic region, causing Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, characterized by inflammation of the liver capsule. This condition manifests with right upper quadrant pain and mild liver enzyme elevation, despite normal gallbladder and biliary ultrasound findings. The combination of cervical motion tenderness and right upper quadrant pain suggests the spread of infection from the pelvis to the liver capsule.

Key learning point: Chlamydia trachomatis is a common cause of pelvic inflammatory disease and can lead to Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, characterized by pelvic and perihepatic adhesions.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman with recurrent pelvic inflammatory disease presents with acute lower abdominal pain and a positive pregnancy test. Which factor best explains her increased risk of ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), often caused by infections like Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae, leads to inflammation and subsequent scarring of the fallopian tubes. This scarring disrupts normal ciliary function and muscular contractions, impairing the transport of the fertilized ovum to the uterine cavity. Consequently, the embryo may implant within the scarred segment of the tube, resulting in an ectopic pregnancy. Recurrent PID episodes exacerbate tubal damage, further increasing the risk of ectopic implantation.

Key learning point: Pelvic inflammatory disease is a significant predisposing factor for ectopic pregnancy due to the potential for scarring and damage to the fallopian tubes.

B) INCORRECT:

Endometrial hyperplasia involves thickening of the uterine lining due to unopposed estrogen exposure, often leading to abnormal uterine bleeding and increased risk of endometrial carcinoma. It does not affect fallopian tube function or transport of the fertilized ovum, which are critical in ectopic pregnancy pathogenesis.

C) INCORRECT:

Ovarian hormone insufficiency affects ovulation and endometrial preparation but is not linked to ectopic pregnancy. A positive pregnancy test indicates sufficient ovarian function. Ectopic pregnancy is primarily associated with tubal damage from conditions like PID.

D) INCORRECT:

Submucosal uterine fibroids are benign tumors within the uterine cavity that may cause abnormal bleeding or infertility. They do not affect fallopian tube function or structure, which are central to ectopic pregnancy development. Tubal damage from PID is the key factor in ectopic pregnancy risk.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman with two prior episodes of pelvic inflammatory disease presents with sudden lower abdominal pain and a missed period. She has a positive pregnancy test. What most likely explains her increased risk of an extrauterine pregnancy?

choices.text: Excess production of human chorionic gonadotropin
Unopposed estrogen leading to endometrial hyperplasia
Chronic tubal scarring from previous infection
Congenital anomaly of the uterine cavity

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Excess human chorionic gonadotropin (hCG) is associated with conditions like gestational trophoblastic disease or multiple gestations. It is a marker of pregnancy, not a cause of ectopic implantation. The increased risk of ectopic pregnancy in this patient is due to tubal damage from pelvic inflammatory disease, not hormonal excess.

B) INCORRECT:

Unopposed estrogen causes endometrial hyperplasia, which can lead to endometrial carcinoma, not ectopic pregnancies. The patient's increased risk of ectopic pregnancy is due to fallopian tube scarring from pelvic inflammatory disease, not endometrial changes.

C) CORRECT:

Pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) causes inflammation in the fallopian tubes, leading to fibrosis and scarring. This scarring disrupts normal ciliary action and peristalsis, impairing the transport of the fertilized ovum to the uterine cavity. As a result, the blastocyst may implant within the tubal epithelium, increasing the risk of an ectopic pregnancy. Tubal damage from PID is a significant predisposing factor for extrauterine pregnancies.

Key learning point: Pelvic inflammatory disease is a major predisposing factor for ectopic pregnancy due to the potential for scarring and damage to the fallopian tubes.

D) INCORRECT:

Congenital uterine anomalies, such as a septate or bicornuate uterus, are linked to recurrent miscarriages and malpresentation, not ectopic pregnancies. The patient's history of pelvic inflammatory disease, leading to tubal scarring, is the relevant factor for increased ectopic pregnancy risk.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to your clinic with pelvic pain and vaginal discharge that began 2 days ago. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 39°C. On pelvic examination, there is pain with movement of the cervix and mucopurulent cervical discharge. Gram stain of the discharge does not show any organisms, but Giemsa stain reveals intracytoplasmic inclusions. Which one of the following complications is she at increased risk for?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Purulent arthritis is a complication of disseminated Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. While N. gonorrhoeae is a relatively common cause of PID, this pathogen is visible on Gram stain and does not show on Giemsa stain (unlike this patient's findings). A complication of Chlamydia trachomatis infection (which this patient has) is reactive arthritis, not purulent arthritis.

B) INCORRECT:

Aortic root dilatation is associated with tertiary syphilis, which results from infection with Treponema pallidum. Patients with PID may have concomitant syphilis. However, the initial manifestations of syphilis are chancre and lymphadenopathy (primary syphilis), which are not present in this patient. Additionally, infection with Treponema pallidum does not typically cause cervical tenderness or discharge.

C) INCORRECT:

Cervical cancer is more strongly associated with HPV infection rather than Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Unprotected intercourse, which most likely caused PID in this patient, increases the risk of HPV infection. Cervical cancer rates are higher in women who have had PID than in the general population, but this is most likely due to increased rates of HPV infection rather than the effect of PID.

D) INCORRECT:

The etiology of endometriosis is thought to be multifactorial. Retrograde menstruation, lymphogenic and hematogenic dissemination of endometrial cells, changes in immunity and endocrine signaling, and genetic factors all play a role in the pathogenesis of endometriosis. Chlamydial infection and PID are not known to contribute to the development of endometriosis.

E) CORRECT:

PID can cause fallopian tube scarring with stenosis, possibly resulting in ectopic pregnancy and/or infertility. Other complications of PID include chronic pelvic pain and Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. PID is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Obtaining vaginal and/or cervical swabs for nucleic acid amplification tests and/or culture for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis is recommended for all patients.

Key learning point: Pelvic inflammatory disease increases the risk of ectopic pregnancy and infertility due to fallopian tube scarring and stenosis.
questions.hint: Intracytoplasmic inclusions on Giemsa stain of this patient's cervical discharge suggest infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. This patient's presentation (cervical motion tenderness, mucopurulent cervical discharge) raises concern for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman comes to your clinic with a 3-day history of lower abdominal pain and dysuria. She has a history of recurrent urinary tract infections that have resolved with antibiotics. She is sexually active with one male partner, and they do not use condoms. She reports mild pain during her last sexual intercourse 1 week ago. Her temperature is 38.2°C, pulse is 86/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. On examination, she has lower abdominal tenderness and bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. There is a small amount of purulent vaginal discharge. Bimanual examination reveals uterine and cervical motion tenderness. A urine pregnancy test is negative. Which one of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: Intramuscular ceftriaxone, oral doxycycline, and oral metronidazole.

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral administration of levofloxacin and metronidazole is suitable for treating PID in patients with cephalosporin allergies. This patient has no history of allergy; a different regimen is preferred.

B) INCORRECT:

Ceftriaxone is typically recommended for the treatment of PID because it covers N. gonorrhoeae, one of the most common causative pathogens. However, empiric antibiotic treatment for PID should also provide coverage for Chlamydia trachomatis, another common causative pathogen, and anaerobes. Ceftriaxone therapy alone is inappropriate.

C) CORRECT:

PID is a clinical diagnosis that is made in sexually active individuals with abdominal and/or pelvic pain if there is no other suspected cause and pelvic examination shows adnexal, uterine, and/or cervical motion tenderness. Patients with PID should be treated with empiric antibiotic therapy that targets the most common causative pathogens, i.e., Neisseria gonorrhoeae (ceftriaxone) and Chlamydia trachomatis (doxycycline), and also covers anaerobes (metronidazole). Outpatient care is preferred for uncomplicated PID. Patients with complicating factors (e.g., pregnancy, suspected tuboovarian abscess, high fever) should be hospitalized and treated with intravenous antibiotics.

Patients with PID should be advised to abstain from sexual activity until antibiotic therapy has been completed, symptoms have resolved, and sexual partners have been treated. All patients diagnosed with PID should also undergo testing for other sexually transmitted infections, including HIV and syphilis.

Key learning point: Empiric outpatient treatment of pelvic inflammatory disease requires antibiotics covering Neisseria gonorrhoeae, Chlamydia trachomatis, and anaerobes—typically ceftriaxone, doxycycline, and metronidazole.

D) INCORRECT:

Metronidazole is effective against infection with anaerobic protozoa and should be part of the empiric antibiotic regimen for PID. Metronidazole alone, however, does not cover the most typical causative pathogens of PID, i.e., N. gonorrhea and C. trachomatis.

E) INCORRECT:

Intramuscular ceftriaxone is used in the treatment of PID. Oral azithromycin can be used to treat infection with Chlamydia trachomatis, which is one of the most common causative organisms of PID, but another regimen is preferred. Furthermore, PID should also be treated with antibiotics that provide anaerobic coverage.
questions.hint: The onset of lower abdominal pain, dysuria, dyspareunia, and purulent vaginal discharge, in conjunction with uterine and cervical motion tenderness in a sexually active woman, is highly suggestive of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl comes to the emergency department with a 5-day history of severe abdominal pain, cramping, nausea, and vomiting. She also reports dysuria. She is sexually active with one male partner and uses condoms inconsistently. She experienced burning pain during her last sexual intercourse 3 days ago. Her temperature is 38.5°C, pulse is 83/min, and blood pressure is 110/70 mm Hg. On examination, there is abdominal tenderness in the lower quadrants.
