Pelvic examination reveals cervical motion tenderness and purulent cervical discharge. Laboratory studies show a white blood cell count of 15.0 × 109/L (3.5–10.5) and an erythrocyte sedimentation rate of 100 mm/h (0–20). Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient presents with dysuria and lower abdominal pain, both of which are symptoms of cystitis. However, cystitis does not typically manifest with cervical motion tenderness or vaginal discharge, although gross hematuria may be present. In addition, the pain of cystitis tends to be localized suprapubically rather than in both lower abdominal quadrants.

B) CORRECT:

This patient presents with characteristic findings of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), i.e., lower abdominal pain (typically bilateral), cervical motion tenderness, and purulent vaginal discharge. Other manifestations of PID include dyspareunia, dysuria, leukocytosis, and an elevated ESR, all of which are seen here. PID is a clinical diagnosis.

Empiric antibiotic therapy that covers Chlamydia trachomatis, Neisseria gonorrhoeae, and anaerobes should be initiated immediately in patients with suspected PID to prevent complications (e.g., infertility due to fallopian tube damage). Obtaining vaginal and/or cervical swabs for nucleic acid amplification tests and/or culture for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis is recommended for all patients with suspected PID to identify pathogens and adjust antibiotic therapy.

Key learning point: Pelvic inflammatory disease is characterized by lower abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, purulent cervical discharge, and systemic signs of infection in sexually active women.

C) INCORRECT:

This patient's lower abdominal pain, purulent discharge, dyspareunia, and dysuria are all characteristic of vulvovaginitis. However, the pelvic examination shows cervical motion tenderness, which is characteristic of inflammation of the upper reproductive tract rather than the vulva or vagina. She also has symptoms that are generally more severe than those caused by vulvovaginitis (e.g., severe pain, fever).

D) INCORRECT:

An ovarian cyst rupture causes sudden, unilateral lower abdominal pain and typically occurs during periods of physical activity (e.g., exercise, sexual intercourse). This patient's pain is bilateral, and although she had dyspareunia during sexual intercourse 3 days ago, her symptoms began 2 days prior to that. Moreover, the pain of a ruptured ovarian cyst is usually not associated with signs of infection such as fever or purulent discharge

E) INCORRECT:

Pyelonephritis can also manifest with fever, nausea, dysuria, and abdominal or pelvic pain. However, patients with pyelonephritis typically also have unilateral flank pain and costovertebral angle tenderness. Furthermore, this patient's other features (e.g., cervical motion tenderness, purulent vaginal discharge, dyspareunia) are not consistent with pyelonephritis.
questions.hint: This patient's condition should be suspected in sexually active women of reproductive age, who present with lower abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, and purulent cervical discharge.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman presents with 4 days of worsening lower abdominal pain and dysuria. She has a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus and takes insulin. She reports new vaginal discharge. Vital signs are BP, 110/70; P, 92; R, 20; T, 38.8°C (101.8°F). Pelvic examination shows mucopurulent cervical discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and bilateral adnexal tenderness. Pregnancy test is negative. Blood glucose is 180 mg/dL. She has no known drug allergies. What is the most appropriate management?

choices.text: Discharge home after IM ceftriaxone with oral doxycycline for 14 days
Discharge home with oral azithromycin for 14 days
Inpatient admission for parenteral clindamycin and gentamicin
Discharge home with oral doxycycline for 14 days
Inpatient admission for parenteral cefotetan and doxycycline

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While this regimen provides adequate outpatient antibiotic coverage for pelvic inflammatory disease, this patient has a fever > 38.5°C (101.3°F), which is an indication for inpatient management with parenteral antibiotics.

B) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin alone does not provide adequate coverage for gonorrhea and is not recommended as a first-line therapy for pelvic inflammatory disease. Additionally, the patient's fever indicates the need for inpatient management.

C) INCORRECT:

While this combination regimen provides adequate coverage for pelvic inflammatory disease, it is reserved for patients with penicillin/cephalosporin allergies. An alternative regimen is more appropriate in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Doxycycline monotherapy does not provide adequate coverage for gonorrhea and is ineffective treatment for pelvic inflammatory disease. Combination therapy that provides coverage for both chlamydia and gonorrhea is required in this patient.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient meets the criteria for inpatient management because they have a fever of > 38.3°C (101°F). The combination of parenteral cefotetan and doxycycline provides appropriate empiric coverage for Chlamydia trachomatis and Neisseria gonorrhoeae.

questions.text: A 26-year-old sexually active woman presents with a 5-day history of pelvic pain and fever. She has cervical motion tenderness and bilateral adnexal tenderness. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F). Leukocyte count is 15,000/μL. Transvaginal ultrasound shows a 4.5-cm complex cystic mass with thick walls and internal echoes in the left adnexa. She also reports new-onset right upper quadrant pain that began 2 days ago. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Urine pregnancy test and pelvic MRI
Hospital admission with IV antibiotics and surgical consultation
Conservative management with IV antibiotics and serial examinations
CT abdomen and pelvis with contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

While pregnancy testing is important, the ultrasound findings already confirm tubo-ovarian abscess requiring immediate inpatient treatment. Additional imaging would inappropriately delay management.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's complex cystic adnexal mass > 4 cm with thick walls is consistent with a tubo-ovarian abscess. Hospital admission for IV antibiotics is mandatory, and surgical consultation is indicated for abscesses > 3 cm. The right upper quadrant pain suggests possible Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome, which also warrants aggressive inpatient management.

C) INCORRECT:

Conservative management is associated with high rates of treatment failure for abscesses of this size. Drainage is typically indicated for most abscesses > 3 cm, and this patient has a 4.5-cm tubo-ovarian abscess.

D) INCORRECT:

Outpatient management is contraindicated in patients with a tubo-ovarian abscess. A complex cystic adnexal mass > 4 cm requires inpatient IV antibiotics and potential drainage procedures.

E) INCORRECT:

Additional imaging would delay necessary treatment. The ultrasound findings and clinical presentation are consistent with tubo-ovarian abscess requiring immediate inpatient management.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with a 5-day history of worsening bilateral lower abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting. She reports a new, malodorous vaginal discharge and pain during intercourse. Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago, and she is sexually active with a new partner. Her temperature is 38.2°C (100.8°F), pulse is 98/min, and blood pressure is 118/76 mm Hg. Abdominal examination shows suprapubic tenderness without rebound or guarding. Pelvic examination shows purulent cervical discharge. Bimanual examination elicits significant cervical motion tenderness and bilateral adnexal tenderness without palpable masses. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Appendicitis is a common cause of lower abdominal pain and fever in this age group. However, the pain in appendicitis is typically unilateral, localizing to the right lower quadrant, whereas this patient's pain is bilateral. The presence of purulent cervical discharge, cervical motion tenderness, and dyspareunia strongly suggests a gynecologic rather than a gastrointestinal cause.

B) CORRECT:

This patient's presentation is classic for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID), an infection of the upper female genital tract. The diagnosis is made clinically based on the presence of lower abdominal pain in a sexually active young woman with one or more of the following on pelvic examination: cervical motion tenderness, uterine tenderness, or adnexal tenderness. This patient has all three. Additional findings that support the diagnosis include fever, new vaginal discharge, and dyspareunia.

PID is typically an ascending infection from the cervix, most commonly caused by Neisseria gonorrhoeae and Chlamydia trachomatis. A new sexual partner is a significant risk factor. Prompt empiric antibiotic treatment is crucial to prevent long-term complications such as infertility and ectopic pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Ovarian torsion manifests with adnexal tenderness and lower abdominal pain. However, the pain is typically of sudden onset, severe, and unilateral. This patient's pain is bilateral and has been worsening over several days. Additionally, fever and purulent cervical discharge are not characteristic findings of ovarian torsion.

D) INCORRECT:

Ectopic pregnancy can manifest with lower abdominal pain, adnexal tenderness, nausea, and vomiting in a sexually active woman. However, these symptoms usually appear 4–6 weeks after the last normal menstrual period, whereas this patient's last period was just 2 weeks ago. Furthermore, fever and purulent vaginal discharge are not typical features of an ectopic pregnancy.
questions.hint: This patient's condition should be suspected in sexually active women of reproductive age who present with lower abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, and purulent cervical discharge.

questions.text:
A 33-year-old woman presents with a five-day history of lower abdominal pain and intermittent fever. She has no known drug allergies. She appears uncomfortable but hemodynamically stable. Pelvic examination reveals moderate tenderness (see report).


Heart rate
88/min


Blood pressure
110/70 mm Hg


Temperature
38.1°C


Transvaginal ultrasound: 4-cm left adnexal complex fluid collection with thick septations
Which of the following is the most appropriate management step?

choices.text: Oral antibiotics on an outpatient basis

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A tubo-ovarian abscess, indicated by a complex fluid collection with thick septations on imaging, is a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease. The patient's symptoms of lower abdominal pain, fever, and adnexal tenderness, along with the ultrasound findings, suggest an abscess requiring prompt treatment. In hemodynamically stable patients without rupture or severe sepsis, intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics are the standard management. This approach targets anaerobes, Gram-negative, and Gram-positive bacteria commonly involved in pelvic infections, aligning with guidelines for managing such infections while monitoring for potential deterioration.

Key learning point: Intravenous antibiotic therapy is the first-line treatment for stable patients with tubo-ovarian abscesses, with surgical intervention reserved for cases unresponsive to medical management or with complications.

B) INCORRECT:

Immediate laparoscopic drainage is not necessary for a hemodynamically stable patient with a 4-cm abscess. This intervention is typically reserved for larger abscesses, significant sepsis, or failure to respond to antibiotics. The current presentation warrants initial treatment with broad-spectrum antibiotics, which is less invasive and appropriate for managing small to moderate tubo-ovarian abscesses.

C) INCORRECT:

Oral antibiotics are suitable for uncomplicated pelvic inflammatory disease, not for a tubo-ovarian abscess with complex adnexal fluid collection. The imaging findings and symptom duration indicate a complicated infection requiring intravenous antibiotics for adequate tissue penetration and to prevent complications.

D) INCORRECT:

Immediate laparotomy is reserved for cases with generalized peritonitis, hemodynamic instability, or ruptured abscess. The patient is stable with moderate tenderness and a modestly sized fluid collection, indicating a conservative approach with antibiotics rather than invasive surgery.

questions.text: A 19-year-old woman comes to the physician because of pelvic pain and vaginal discharge that began 2 days ago. She has no history of serious medical illness and takes no medications. Her temperature is 39°C (102.2°F). Pelvic examination shows pain with movement of the cervix and mucopurulent cervical discharge. A Gram stain of the discharge does not show any organisms. A Giemsa stain shows intracytoplasmic inclusions. The patient's current condition puts her at increased risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Trophoblastic neoplasias include hydatidiform moles (complete and partial) and choriocarcinoma, which are characterized by abnormal proliferation of trophoblastic tissue. Neither chlamydia infection nor PID is associated with the development of these conditions.

B) INCORRECT:

Cervical cancer is more strongly associated with HPV infection rather than Chlamydia trachomatis infection. Unprotected intercourse, which most likely caused PID in this patient, increases the risk of HPV infection. Cervical cancer rates are higher in women who have had PID than in the general population, but this is most likely due to increased rates of HPV infection rather than the effect of PID.

C) INCORRECT:

The etiology of endometriosis is thought to be multifactorial. Retrograde menstruation, lymphogenic and hematogenic dissemination of endometrial cells, changes in immunity and endocrine signaling, and genetic factors all play a role in the pathogenesis of endometriosis. Chlamydial infection and PID are not known to contribute to the development of endometriosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Aortic root dilatation is associated with tertiary syphilis, which results from infection with Treponema pallidum. Patients with PID may have concomitant syphilis. However, the initial manifestations of syphilis are chancre and lymphadenopathy (primary syphilis), which are not present in this patient. Additionally, infection with Treponema pallidum does not typically cause cervical tenderness or discharge.

E) INCORRECT:

Purulent arthritis is a complication of disseminated Neisseria gonorrhoeae infection. While N. gonorrhoeae is a relatively common cause of PID, this pathogen is visible on Gram stain and does not show on Giemsa stain (unlike this patient's findings). A complication of Chlamydia trachomatis infection (which this patient has) is reactive arthritis, not purulent arthritis.

F) CORRECT:

PID can cause fallopian tube scarring with stenosis, possibly resulting in ectopic pregnancy and/or infertility. Other complications of PID include chronic pelvic pain and Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome. PID is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis or Neisseria gonorrhoeae. Obtaining vaginal and/or cervical swabs for nucleic acid amplification tests and/or culture for N. gonorrhoeae and C. trachomatis is recommended for all patients.
questions.hint: Intracytoplasmic inclusions on Giemsa stain of this patient's cervical discharge suggest infection with Chlamydia trachomatis. This patient's presentation (cervical motion tenderness, mucopurulent cervical discharge) raises concern for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID).
